title: Z-RO - Heroin Album
description:
Even though it appears to be an album of brand new material, Heroin is in fact Rap-A-LotÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s attempt to collect and repackage various Z-RO songs from the past few years. And though it may have been released without input or even approval from the rapper himself, Heroin holds up as a capsule view of RoÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s recent output. The opening three songs provide a deadly combination. Mike DeanÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œNever Let It GoÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ is brawny Houston funk that would make Pimp C proud. Even though the song is almost a year old, mixtape favorite ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œDenzel WashingtonÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ holds up to the any of 2010ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s massive street anthems. Most crucial of all, ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œDriving Me WildÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ brings to bears all of Z-ROÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s essential qualities ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ his deft rapping, soulful singing, and love for a brooding atmosphere. The remainder of the album is spotty but the material is never less than stellar, and ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œDo Bad On My Own,ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œEyez On da PrizeÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ and ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œCome Back Wit ItÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ confirm Z-ROÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s reputation as one of the few true heavyweights of this era.
